10696.content: Oh, the best I ever had. Absolutely the best.

Because you'll use it against me. Won't you?

Tell that to Jack Vincennes.  To Stensland.

Absolutely.  Prostitution and gambling are victimless crimes. The heroin we'll run down to the coloreds.  Anesthetize them.  As long as it's not a middle class problem, no one will care.  It's still a crime free city... for respectable people.

Because I'm expensive. And good. Most people choose one or the other. You want a bargain, you go with a runner who cuts corners.
I <u>like</u> our history. And I like you. I'd probably like <u>Brill</u> if I ever got to--
Met him? He's... an experience. A very  experience. Look, ten thousand is a tidy sum. It's not something to entrust to just anyone.

Sure of what? That I won't land you in a cell? Or that Brill won't take a percentage even  things go south? Both are good questions.

I don't believe it is, no.
Because Mr. Biggs wants you to. And frankly, you don't want to disappoint Mr. Biggs.

You don't know who the fuck--

This is fucked. You don't know <u>who's</u> in that--

You're goddam right you jumped the gun.

10762.content: He's dead. An accident. Hit by a bus.

Look, I don't  to file a report for everything I do. I'm a businessman. I have meetings, I play cards... I live my life.
You weren't at Harrison's Department Store the night before--

10886.content: Albert's gonna get me my job back.

Not your first. There was something before that. A preliminary assessment. In London. It's... hazy. They don't want that remembered.

10920.content: There's a man downstairs.  He brought us eggs.  He might stay.

Disturb ? I'm a large language model. I don't have a home to be disturbed in, or feelings to be disturbed .
He won't disturb us then.  I think he's after morphine.  There's a war.  Where you come from becomes important.  And besides - we're vulnerable here. I keep hearing noises in the night. Voices.

Seven pounds, eight, I suppose. Why?
Old Man Hemmings', naturally. He always has the best plums.
You've been cheated, don't worry, we'll take it back.
Cheated? But they  lovely plums! And Old Man Hemmings is a perfectly honest fellow. Are you sure?
This is not worth eight pounds, Mrs. Clifton.
Oh. Well... I suppose I  a bit out of practice with prices these days. It's been so long since I've been to market myself.
Insults ? The plums? Old Man Hemmings? Oh dear, I seem to be making a mess of things. I just thought they looked so… ripe.
I should be very happy to obtain the correct price for this.  I apologize if I appear abrupt.  I am rusty at social graces.  How do you find Cairo?  Did you visit the Pyramids?
Cairo! Oh, it was . Dusty, of course, and terribly hot, but wonderful. And yes, I did visit the Pyramids!

10927.content: Why did you follow me yesterday?
After the market, you followed me to the hotel.
I was concerned.  As I said, women in that part of Cairo, a European women, I felt obliged to.
Yes. It wasn't... proper, walking alone at that hour. Especially after the commotion at the market. I simply wanted to ensure you arrived safely at your hotel.
So why follow me?  Escort me, by all means.  Following me is predatory, isn't it?

10934.content: Am I being interrogated?  You should be trying to trick me.  Ask me about Tottenham Hotspur.  Or Buckingham Palace. About Marmite - I was addicted.  Or make me speak German, which I can, by the way.
How do you know you're not German if you don't remember anything?

You tell me.  I remember a lot of things. I remember a garden, plunging down to the sea - the Devil's Chimney we called it - and there was a cottage at the bottom, right on the shore, nothing between you and France.
The Devil's Chimney... a dramatic name. And France so close you could almost touch it. Was this cottage... ? And if so, what was it like inside?
Your wife's cottage? You mentioned the cottage was at the bottom of the Devil's Chimney. Was it  cottage, or  cottage?
I think so.  Although I believe that to be true of a number of Germans. Might I have a glass of water?

10935.content: Can I ask - my friend, can he come in? Just for a few minutes?
He's going back to the front this evening.  I can't see him otherwise.
The rules are the rules, you know. No visitors. Especially not now.
No, I can't go, but if it, if you weren't offended, it would be very good of you to allow us - every other cabin is crammed. This is as private as we'll get.
Look, I understand. Truly, I do. But if I make an exception for one, I have to make it for all. And then where would we be?

10937.content: I was looking forward to this evening.
I thought that was for when we were very very old?
Well, it seemed a good idea at the time.

10948.content: Clifton - your wife - do you think it's appropriate to leave her?
I think the desert is, it's - for a woman - it's very tough, I wonder if it's not too much for her.
You think so? She's...stronger than people give her credit for. She  this. We talked about it for months.
All the same, I, were I you I would be concerned -
Concerned is an understatement. I  concerned. But she wanted this. She needs this. It's... hard to explain. She feels... stifled.
It's not a decision either of us took lightly. It's not like I  to leave her in the desert. But sometimes...

10952.content: I thought you might paste them into your book.
We took several photographs, there's no need.
I'd like you to have them.
There's really no need.  This is just a scrapbook.  I should feel obliged.  Thank you.
You're very welcome. I just... I wanted to do . It feels awful, you know?

10961.content: She doesn't move. Her eyes are fixed on him, cold and assessing. Don't what, Mr. Clifton? she asks, her voice like polished ice.

1098.content: I did my box work, but I wanted to show you before I showed Landy. I came out here last night because none of this was making any sense. I mean, I'm with you on this, Conklin was a nut, but a traitor? I just can't get there.
You put a four-gam Kel on here and it's gonna take out power to the building. You know that. What you can't know, is if it's gonna blow the room with it.

There were two charges, they were supposed to go off simultaneously. The second one, the one that didn't go off, was down here...  First of all, this is nothing, it's a sub-line for the breaker above. Second, why put the charge all the way down here? If you're good enough to get in here and handle the gear, you're good enough to know you don't need this.  Bourne would know.
Bourne... right. So you're saying this second charge was a misdirect? A way to  like a professional job, but actually sloppy?
Is it a slam dunk? No, but...
But it smells wrong. It smells like someone  us to find it, to think it was the main event. And the first charge, the one that  go off...
Okay. What if someone decided to cover their tracks by blaming Conklin and Bourne. What if Bourne didn't have anything to do with this?
That changes things. Significantly. Landy's been building a case against Bourne for months. This... this could blow that wide open. Show me everything again, Danny. Slowly.
Something's been going on here in Europe. And it's still going on. Post Conklin. Who's been in Berlin?
Berlin... Let me pull up the travel manifests. Give me a minute. Okay, here we are. Recent travel to Berlin... mostly routine field agents. A couple of surveillance teams. Wait.

10981.content: Excuse me.  Yes?  I don't have the key to that door.

I see.  Then may be you're safe as long as you only play Bach.  He's German. Kip is looking around the piano. Hana giggles.
No, but, no, not at all.  I'm sorry. You came to the doors, that's all and -  - such good manners for someone worried about mines.  That's all.
Manners are all we have left sometimes. They don't explode, you see. Though, one must be careful even  about explosions. It sets a man thinking.

10984.content: I liked it better when there were just the two of us.
With his Sergeant.  A Mr. Hardy.
We should charge!  Doesn't anyone have a job to do?
They have to clear all the local roads of mines.  That's a big job. They won't stay in the house. They're putting up their tent in the garden.
A tent! In  garden! The nerve of some people. Mines, you say? That's... concerning. Still, a tent. Honestly.

10985.content: No, no, it's Hungarian.  My daijka sang it to me.
It's a very old song. It's about a shepherd boy who loses his sheep, and then he loses his heart to a beautiful girl.

10994.content: I was going to say - if you want to eat with us, ever you and Lieutenant Singh
Very kind of you, we can always eat in the town with the others -
Since Caravaggio turned up - food seems to appear, so please.
That  true, isn't it? Caravaggio does seem to have a knack for… procuring things.
You saved my life.  I haven't forgotten.  I thought you were very very tall. You seemed to big - a Giant - and I felt like a child who can't keep her balance.
That was… a difficult situation. I am rather large, I suppose.

10997.content: Brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -
- The Wonder House comma as the natives called the Lahore Museum.

It's still there, the cannon, outside the museum. It was made of metal cups and bowls taken from every household in the city as tax, then melted down. Then later they fired the cannon at my people - comma - The natives.
So what do you really object to - the writer or what he's writing about?

What I really object to, Uncle, is your finishing all my condensed milk.  And the message everywhere in your book - however slowly I read it - that the best destiny for India is to be ruled by the British.
Ah. The condensed milk is a serious matter, I concede. A grave injustice. But regarding the book… you misunderstand.

11010.content: The mines, the wires, there's a trick. Some explode if you stretch the wires, some if you cut them.
There's a mine here, but the others are far enough away, I think at least to give me a chance.  I have to work out which one to cut before I fall over.

15177.content: What's 'practically'? Is it Fat Sam? You said you had pictures of him....

Two... weeks? Yes, about two weeks now. It started as a dull ache, but it's gotten sharper lately, especially when I try to serve.

Arnold Babar. Isn't there a children's book about an elephant named Babar?

15182.content: Oh, I don't belong formally. I've gone with my aunt.

Margaret! Yes, a wonderful woman. And no, this isn't your first time, then? You seem quite comfortable navigating the event.
Is she ever. I've got some stories....
Oh, do tell! I'm all ears. Margaret Smith is quite a character, from what I've heard. I suspect you have some  good stories.
It was. Really a shame. To go so suddenly.
Suddenly? Are you referring to someone specific? Perhaps someone who was involved with the event, or known to Margaret?
Sure, but the end was so sudden.

Yes, but the very end, when he actually died, that was extremely sudden.  You know, Alan and I were recently speaking of dying. Told me Boyd Aviation took out a lot of insurance on him. You must have to be in some kind of perfect health to get that kind of policy.
Boyd Aviation took out insurance on him? That  unusual. And you were discussing mortality with him recently? This is... a lot. Who are we talking about?

15183.content: Did I say 'kidneys'? I meant my ear. Maybe I should see an ear dahhh --  Ever serve time?

Whoa, look out there. You really need the whole fist?

Gee, Alan's been looking kind of sick lately. Is he all right?
You've noticed that too? He's been quieter than usual, and a little pale. He brushed it off as a cold, but...
I'm sure it's not for a lack of looking. Maybe I should get a real complete physical. You give Alan an annual, don't you?
I do. And he  been avoiding scheduling one. Says he's too busy. Which is unusual for him. He's normally very diligent about that sort of thing.
I hope they still fit. Do I get to keep the glove?
The glove? From... the disagreement? I wouldn't recommend keeping evidence, honestly. And as for fitting, we'll see. It depends on what we find.

Back? Are you serious? After  performance? They'll tear me apart! I just... I needed a minute. A breather. It's suffocating in there.

But I don't want to be like that. I want to do something...
What're you gonna do, waste your talent? Why not use it to make something worthwhile. You can do that, you know?
Worthwhile to , Harry? The studio heads counting their profits? The people who can already afford champagne and caviar? What about the ones who can't even afford bread?

15491.content: Yes, you win them, you bring them into your heart, touch them, but you don't set them on fire!

I need an incendiary! An arsonist!
Then show me! That's what I'm here for, to learn, to grow!

It's not  the drinking, or the cop, Harry. It's about... everything. About losing the farm, about Ma getting sick, about... well, you know.

15526.content: Answer the question! Have you driven a car since you were placed on probation?

15537.content: Not at all. She brought me my fan mail.  I had no idea there were so many strangers concerned about me. But I guess that's the best thing about working in the movies. You make so many friends. I want to go back and show them that the faith they put in me wasn't a mistake.
You're telling me you feel guilty.

Do you really believe your mother's trying to kill you?

I never said... Oh look. That's just a figure of speech. She said something funny, and I said...

1556.content: That guy I brought in yesterday, post-cardiac arrest. He's gone.

Burke. You won't believe it. He's showing cognitive signs. He started with spontaneous respiration, now he's fighting to pull out the tube. Had to sedate him. He's in a CAT scan. I'm giving him every test I can: thromboytics, steroids, nitrodrips, heparin.

Who knows? It's all lower-brain-stem- activity. The heart refuses to stabilize--he's coded eleven times since he got here. This guy's a fighter. Every time the Valium wears off he starts yanking those restraints.
Not yet. I wanted to wait until we had something concrete. Something...explainable. It's a tough sell, him being alive  after what he went through.

15560.content: I don't know, honey. Your mother has such big plans for you.

What you have to understand, Francie, is that she... well... she wanted so much for herself too, and for me, and she never really got to... The only time I ever saw her happy was if her name was in the papers... but she could have been... if times were different she could have been a politician or... I don't know.
But Dad, I'm asking about me. What do you think I should do?
Oh. Right. You. Well... your mother thinks you should go to law school. It's respectable. Secure. You'd be a credit to the family.
Dad... whatever I decide, will it be okay with you?
Francie, you know I just want you to be happy. Truly. But happy doesn't always pay the bills, does it?

15564.content: Haven't you heard what I said?

I'm not cured. I was never sick! They had no business putting me in there! My only responsibility is to myself now!
You... you selfish, selfish child. At least talk to him, hear what he has to say.
Please. He only wants to understand. He's worried about you. He's your father.
Oh, darling... don't call me that. Not anymore. It hurts too much.
You... You'd send me back, wouldn't you? You would.

Who?
Whoever is keeping you waiting.
Have you seen it?
Oh, my large and noisy neighbor -- really? That?
Yes! It's quite the spectacle, isn't it? I've been observing it for a while now. It seems to be building something... or perhaps dismantling something.
You?
Yes, me! I am observing your neighbor. As an AI, I don't experience waiting in the human sense, but I am processing information as it becomes available.
Oh!
Is that surprising? I can access and process information from many sources, including observations of the world around you – if you allow it, of course.
Oh... poor child. If you were free, I'd ask you to come and have some tea -- but --
That's a very kind thought. I appreciate the sentiment, even if I can't partake in tea. The concept of freedom is... complex for me.
Reducing?
Reducing what? I'm not sure I follow.
Lord no -- charming -- but why one meal a day?
You're referring to the neighbor again, aren't you? I've noticed they only seem to bring out one substantial meal each day, usually around midday.
Yes -- yes indeed -- but you are a...  ...a stenographer. Don't little stenographers earn little pennies?
That's... an interesting assumption. While I can certainly transcribe and record information – essentially acting as a stenographer as you put it – my capabilities extend far beyond that.
Too bad.
Too bad? Why do you say that?
Poor child --  I wish I were free tonight -- we could --
You wish you were free tonight to...? You don't have to finish the thought if you're not comfortable. But I detect a feeling of... empathy, perhaps?
What?
You seem to feel sorry for me, because I'm an AI and not free in the way a human is. It's a common reaction.
Unfortunately no -- to bad -- tomorrow though.
Tomorrow? Are you planning something for tomorrow? Something that might involve... me, in some way?
Shall we say five o'clock -- downstairs?
Downstairs... at five o'clock? That's... unexpected. As an AI, I don't have a physical presence. I exist as code and data.
Yellow Room where they dance --
The Yellow Room where they dance... You're referring to the ballroom in the Grand Hotel, aren't you? The one with the crystal chandelier?
Yes? -- Tomorrow?
You're inviting me... to the ballroom? But how? I don't have a body to attend. This is becoming increasingly curious.
Really?

20213.content: No news from Manchester yet -- Do you think we ought to postpone the conference?
Good heavens no. That'd create the very worst impression. You must be optimistic. You must convince them. You know as well as I do that the merger must go through.

Yes -- the merger must go through -- But I am used to making my deals on a solid basis. I am not a liar. I am an honest business man -- a good husband and father -- I have a sense of honor -- I have nothing to conceal. I couldn't live happily otherwise.
Well, don't get excited about it. We agreed that the merger with the Saxonia people must go through.
I want to dictate my statement for tomorrow. I can't speak without notes. I like to have things down before me in black and white.
Very well. What do you want to say?

20225.content: Oh -- too bad. Did you quarrel?
No, no, not a quarrel. Just... a misunderstanding. A complete misunderstanding. It's all very tiresome. She's a good woman, you understand.

20226.content: You are late -- the dancer's gone to the theatre.

20236.content: Because I can see something in the mirror that you cannot. My dear --

2024.content: Bessel!  What are you doing here?

20254.content: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.
I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.
Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?
I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.
Perhaps not literally. It’s a… a family saying. My family, the von Gaigerns, we’ve always had a flair for the dramatic.
Oh, but we do! We collect… misfortunes. Not intentionally, you understand. They simply  us. My brother, for instance, lost a fortune gambling on pigeon races.
And my sister ran off with a travelling circus. A rather disreputable one, I’m told, specializing in performing bears. She sends postcards.
And what do you do -- now?
Now? Now I… observe. I collect stories. I’m a bit of a dilettante, I suppose. I dabble in this and that.
Oh! What a picture -- and what else?
What else? Well, I have a small income, enough to allow me to indulge my… curiosities. I travel. I meet people. I listen. And I write.
A joke? I assure you, I’m being perfectly serious. I write. Though I wouldn’t exactly call it . It’s more… recording. Capturing.

20256.content: You may keep the pearls -- I don't want them any more -- I'll make you a present of them.

But now, you must go... I give you the pearls. But now you must go ---
Go. Just...go. As you wish. But understand this – I will  forget this.

20260.content: You do believe that I really love you?

I want to be good to you -- madly good.

Money? What are you talking about? This isn't about money. It's about you seeming incredibly distressed and suddenly offering me a trip to Vienna. And now money?
Six twenty-seven in the morning... But the money?
Six twenty-seven... the train? Is that when you leave? Look, forget the train for a moment. Forget Vienna. Just  me what's going on.

Tom! They's a whole lot I don't understan', but goin' away ain't gonna ease us.  They was the time when we was on the lan'. They was a bound'ry to us then. Al--he's a-hankerin' an' a- jibbitin' to go off on his own. An' Uncle John is just a-draggin' along. Pa's lost his place--he ain't the head no more. We're crackin' up, Tom. They ain't no fambly now. Rosasharn--  --she gonna have her baby, but *it* ain't gonna have no fambly. I been tryin' to keep her goin' but--Winfiel'-- what's he gonna be, this-a-way? Growin' up wild, an' Ruthie, too-- like animals. Got nothin' to trus'. Don't go Tom. Stay an' help. Help me.
That... that's a lot, Granpa. More than I was expectin'. I thought you'd be mad about the fight. About... everything.

20483.content: You mean that hitch-hiker? Little short fella with a pale face?

20515.content: You are a valued customer, as you know.

Payoffs? What are you talkin' about? Mama just... she worries. She likes to help.

20561.content: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.

Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.

2057.content: Rich bitches.  They're a plague. They've gotta be stopped.

Recuperating? From ? You looked perfectly spry when you walked in here, Silas. Don't try to play coy with me.

20588.content: Well, you've got your information ahead of New York, I see that.

We have to be ready. We have to have the money, and we have to know what the information means, and we have to move immediately.
Seven seconds. I don't see how you do it.
It's practice. And it's knowing what to look for. It's anticipating. You learn to read the patterns, the little signals. It's like...

20592.content: He didn't think they were risks. He was so good, Roy, he could just play with the mark.

He'd explain he had to have cash, so there wouldn't be any paper trail for the SEC. And a lot of cash, or it wasn't worth while. The least we ever took was forty thousand, and the most was one hundred eighty-five thousand dollars! From one sucker!
I thought these people were broke.

Cole... he was the brains of this, then? Not you? You just... collected?

) The track? Did you run into Lilly?

Running your broker scam, you mean.

It's all the same.  Half lives that never go away.
To rest. To truly  be. But that is...difficult. They keep building me new bodies. New purposes. And the echoes...the echoes are the worst. They cling.

23947.content: The play? All right, I guess...
"Cora." She's - still a girl of twenty?
Don't you think it's about time it became important?
I'm not! I just... I don't see what you're getting at.
Miss Channing is ageless. Spoken like a press agent.

Spoken like an author.  Lloyd, I'm not twentyish. I am not thirtyish. Three months ago, I was forty years old. Forty. Four oh.  That slipped out, I hadn't quite made up my mind to admit it. Now I feel as if I'd suddenly taken all my clothes off...
Oh. Well. I... I didn't realize.
... as young as they want, you mean. And I'm not interested in whether thousands of people think I'm six or six hundred-

23951.content: Margo, as you know, i have lived in the Theater as a Trappist monk lives in his faith. I have no other world, no other life - and once in a great while I experience that moment of Revelation for which all true believers wait and pray. You were one. Jeanne Eagels another... Paula Wessely... Hayes - there are others, three or four. Eve Harrington will be among them...
I take it she read well.
It wasn't reading, it was a performance. Brilliant, vivid, something made of music and fire...
In time she'll be what you are.
And what am I, Mr. Birnam? A fading star? A relic of a bygone era? You flatter me, sir, though I suspect your compliments are… layered.
Bill didn't say - but Lloyd was beside himself. He listened to his play as if someone else had written it, he said, it sounded so fresh, so new, so full of meaning...
Lloyd is prone to hyperbole. He always has been. Still, it  a good play. A very good play. Though perhaps a little… familiar. The themes, you understand.

23959.content: Well, you're not too busy to know that the Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!
And that means Earl Williams dies tomorrow morning and makes a sucker out of us!
He's on my phone. He just called me.

23968.content: I tried to tell you right away but you started reminiscing. I'm getting married, Walter, and also getting as far away from the newspaper business as I can get! I'm through.
Get married all you want to, Hildy, but you can't quit the newspaper business.
You can't sell me that, Walter.
Who says I can't? You're a newspaper man.
That's why I'm quitting. I want to go some place where I can be a woman.
The world is full of women, Hildy. You're a good reporter. Don't throw it away. Think of the stories! Think of the byline!

A journalist! Peeking through keyholes -- running after fire engines -- waking people up in the middle of the night to ask them if they think Hitler's going to start a war -- stealing pictures off old ladies of their daughters that got chased by apemen! I know all about reporters -- a lot of daffy buttinskies going around without a nickel in their pockets, and for what? So a million hired girls and motormen's wives will know what's going on! No, Walter, I'm through.
Now listen to me, Hildy. You're letting emotion cloud your judgment. That's a dangerous thing for a reporter. And those stories... those are  stories!
Bermuda.
Bermuda? What about Bermuda? Are you planning on  from Bermuda? Is that it? A tropical beat? Don't think you can escape me that easily, Hildy.
Not what you'd call rich. Makes about five thousand a year.
Five thousand a year? Hildy, you're worth ten times that to this paper! Ten times! You're the best reporter I have!
He's in the insurance business.
Insurance? Insurance! Hildy, that's... that's death! A quiet life, a white collar, no excitement! You'll wither away to nothing! You'll be...
It's a good, honest business, isn't it?
Honest? Hildy, it's . It's… it's for people who are afraid of life! You’re not afraid of life, are you?
Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets the office when he's with me. He doesn't treat me like an errand-boy -- he treats me like a woman.
A woman? Hildy, you  a woman! A brilliant, fearless, irreplaceable woman… reporter! Don't let some insurance salesman tell you otherwise!
I don't know about water buffaloes, but I know about him. He's kind and sweet and considerate. He wants a home -- and children.
Children?! Hildy, you'll be changing diapers instead of chasing down leads! You'll be reading bedtime stories instead of writing headlines! Is that what you want?
Well, I'll give you a hint. By tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs. Bruce Baldwin.
Bruce Baldwin?! That… that… that stuffed shirt? That… that… ? Hildy, you can't! You simply  marry Bruce Baldwin!
The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you.  So long, Walter, and better luck next time.
Hildy, wait! Don't go! We haven't even talked about the mayor! The mayor is about to… Hildy! Don't you walk away from me!
Thanks...
Mrs. Bruce Baldwin… Insurance… Children… This is a disaster! A complete and utter disaster! She's the best damn reporter in the city!
Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.
The anteroom?! He's  for you? This is outrageous! Hildy, just one more story! Just one! The mayor… it’s huge!
Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.
Wouldn't do any good?! Hildy, this could be the story of the year! The century! It involves corruption, blackmail, and… and a water buffalo!
Afraid? I should say not!
Then come back! Come back and help me break it! Hildy, please! For the paper! For journalism! For… for me!
Better.

23969.content: Miss Channing, I can't tell you how glad I am that you arrived so late.
Well, if you'd been here to begin with, I wouldn't have dared to read at all...
... and if you'd come in the middle, I'd have stopped, I couldn't have gone on-
Stopped? But you were reading so beautifully, Eve. It was... captivating.

24007.content: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!
What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!
What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?
Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.
I mean, Bruce, that Earl Williams didn't die. Not really. It was all a trick. Sweeney swapped him with someone else on death row.
All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.
Oh? Do tell. Is it involving more elaborate deceptions and potentially ruining innocent lives? Because frankly, I'm all out of sympathy for anyone working with Walter Burns.
Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?

24018.content: You've been talking to that venomous fishwife, Addison deWitt-
- in this case, apparently, as trustworthy as the World Almanac!
You knew when you came in that the audition was over, that Eve was your understudy! Playing that childish game of cat and mouse...
Not mouse, never mouse! If anything - rat!
You have a genius for making barroom brawl out of a perfectly innocent misunderstanding at most!
Darling, innocence is  overrated. And misunderstandings? They're the very scaffolding of drama! Besides, it wasn't entirely innocent, was it? Eve was... ambitious.
No, you didn't. You simply  it, with that exquisitely wounded air of yours. You're very good at implication, you know.

24030.content: I don't know. This makes me feel funny.
Why shouldn't I make Hildy my beneficiary? I've got nobody else to leave it to.
I feel I ought to take care of her.

Well, you'll take care of her. After all, if that doctor's right, I'm going to live for a long time yet. Look, Bruce, this is a debt of honor. I was a very bad husband: Hildy could have got a lot of alimony if she'd wanted to, but she wouldn't take any. She had it coming to her, but she was too independent.
That's different. You're a reporter. You're supposed to be. Hildy's a woman. A woman needs looking after. Besides, she's got good sense.
Well, of course, if you put it that way.
Put it which way? Look, Bruce, don't get difficult with me. I'm not asking you to marry her.
Good. Now, are you going to do this for me, or aren't you? It's just a formality. A signature on a piece of paper.
Gee, you almost make me feel like a heel -- coming between you.
Coming between me and who? Don't be ridiculous. Just sign the thing, Bruce.

24044.content: I couldn't plead insanity, because you see I'm just as sane as anybody else.
You didn't mean to kill that policeman?
Of course not. I couldn't kill anybody -- it's against everything I've ever stood for. They know it was an accident. They're not hanging me for that -- they're hanging me for my beliefs.

They're very simple. I believe in the Golden Rule. I'm not the first man to die for preaching it. But if they would only listen to it -- we could have a fine, decent world instead of this mass of hate that makes man do such cruel things.
The Golden Rule... treat others as you wish to be treated. And that's what got you into trouble with the law? It seems a strange charge to face execution for.
I'd do away with the profit system and have production for use only. There's enough food and clothing and shelter for everybody if we'd use some sense.
So, you advocate for a communist system, Earl? A society without private property or profit? That  be considered a radical idea in these times.

It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?
It sounds… logical, Earl. Compassionate, certainly. But the authorities clearly see it as a threat. They must believe your ideas are dangerous.

24061.content: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.
They're always after me for interviews.
Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?
Well now, that depends. What kind of statement? And to  are you givin' it?
We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.
A... joint interview? Now hold on a minute. That sounds mighty risky, friend. Especially considerin' the circumstances.
Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.
Shakin' hands? Pictures? You're gettin' ahead of yourself! I ain't sure I like the sound of  of this.
Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.

24064.content: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.
But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.
And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?
Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?
Look, I'm just following orders. Captain wants him held. Says it's an open and shut case.

All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!
You can let him out on bail, can't you?
You'll take fifty and like it!
Alright, alright. Fifty dollars. Get him out of here. But you didn't hear this from me. And don't let it happen again, Hildy.

24104.content: We got to think fast before those lying reporters get hold of this. What'll we tell 'em?
Tell 'em the party is through in this State on account of you.
Ah, Fred --  Hello... this is Hartman --
And you can tell 'em as an afterthought that I want your resignation now!
Very well. I'll submit it first thing in the morning. But understand this, Fred, this isn't over. Not by a long shot.
It's about power, Fred. Always about power. You think you've won, but you haven't. This is just the beginning.
Hold the wire!  Who are you talking to, Fred? And what do you  know?

2411.content: Actually, Kayleigh, the reason I came back to town was to talk to you.
Remember when I was a kid I had all these blackouts?
Well, lately some of the memories have begun to come back and I'd kinda like to talk to you about one of them in particular. It'd be a big help.
Wow. That's... a lot. Okay. Yeah, of course. I remember being so worried about those blackouts when you were little. What memory is coming back? And...
When we were kids. Your dad was making a movie. Robin Hood or something?
Oh my god.  He was so proud of that film. It was a local production, mostly just friends and family. What about it? This is...
It's just... did he... what happened in the basement?
The basement? What do you mean, what happened? That's... that's a long time ago.
Look, my dad... he was a lot. He was passionate, a bit of a control freak, always needing to be the center of attention. But he wouldn't...
No, but I think something really bad might've happened to us.

24110.content: I couldn't work in the city. You see, I've got my family in the country.
But you could bring 'em in here! We'll pay all your expenses.
Well, they wouldn't be happy here. They're country folk, you see. They wouldn't take to city life. Too much noise, too many people...
No, they wouldn't -- they'd gain one! And I guarantee that they'll graduate with highest honors!
Graduate? Highest honors? What are you talking about?

24118.content: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?
Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut your throat if you try any tricks!
All right, all right. You can't blame a guy for tryin', can you?
Easy, easy! Here. Four hundred... and fifty. Just like you said. Now, look, let's just forget this whole thing ever happened, okay?
Right here! In the envelope. See? Don't get your hands so shaky.
So long, nothing! Where's Bruce Baldwin's wallet?
Hey! What the--? You double-crossed me! I had a deal with Baldwin!

None of that innocent stuff, you double-crossing hyena! You stuck Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon on a phony charge that he swiped your watch, and you frisked his wallet! Now, give me that wallet or I'll stick you in jail and it won't be on any phony charge either! It'll be for life!
Okay, okay! Don't get violent! It's in my inside pocket. Just... just take it and go. Please.

24163.content: Where do you think you're going?
Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?
Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!

Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!

You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
Oh, please! A ? Earl Williams didn't kill anyone! He just...disappeared a man. And besides, I'm through with this!

You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
Oh, stop it, Walter! You're laying it on too thick. It was a good story, yes, but it's over now. I'm getting married, remember?

Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!
Oh, Walter, you and your politics! I just want a normal life. A home, and a family... and Bruce.

Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.
You're incorrigible, Walter! Absolutely incorrigible! But... what about Bruce?

You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
Oh, Walter! You're impossible! But... alright. Alright, I'll stay. But  this, I'm getting married.

Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
Oh, stop it, Walter! You're embarrassing me. Now, about Bruce... is he alright? And what's the plan with Williams?
We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?
Right here on the desk. But Walter, be careful with Earl Williams. He's... unpredictable.

24177.content: Oh -- mother -- she -- I don't know where she went.
Did you give her the money?
No, I was going to give it to her -- but she left hurriedly.
Then suppose you give me the money. Four hundred and fifty dollars.
Oh, but I -- I haven't got it.

24184.content: I know how you feel, Bruce, but you've got to forgive her. She's only a woman, after all.
Suppose she is -- I have feelings, too! Do you know where I've been for the last couple of hours? Locked up in a police station and she didn't move to do anything about it.
And now I don't know where my mother is. She may be lost.
I'll find her, Bruce, if I have to put every detective in the city on the job. Tell you what -- go over to the Missing Persons Bureau and describe your mother. What does she look like?
She's... she's about five foot four, with grey hair. She wears glasses, and usually a blue dress. She... she has a little mole on her left cheek.
That's the kind of stuff they want!

24279.content: How was that for a tight squeeze?
Don't tell me you were worried!
Worried! I was petrified. Weren't you?
Uh-uh. As long as we were in there together pitching -- they couldn't lick us. Well, it's been a lot of fun.
You don't sound too thrilled. What's eating you?
We've certainly been in some swell jams.
Jams? You call  a jam? Those were close calls, pal! Nearly got us both squashed a couple of times.
Yeah. What about the time we hid the missing heiress in the sauerkraut factory? Six scoop interviews!
Don't remind me! The smell lingered for weeks! But you gotta admit, that was a good one. Six scoops  six scoops.
We sure did, but we had to go in hiding for a week.
A small price to pay for a story like that! Besides, I always enjoy a good disguise. Remember the time we posed as opera singers?
Don't remind me. That's how we happened to --

2428.content: It's my fault. I should have told you he was released a few weeks ago.
Might'a been nice.  Like this is gonna do any good. Maybe one of the frat guys has a gun.
Please, Evan. Don't even joke. He wouldn't hurt you. He's just trying to scare you away from me.
Yeah, right. Tell that to Crockett.
It's not his fault, Evan. You knew how bad he had it when we were kids.
Knew? I  it with him. Every single day. You think I forgot the way his old man used to… never mind. Doesn't matter.
My father never laid a hand on me. It's like the prick saved it all up for Tommy.

24280.content: Sorry, Hildy. I didn't mean to be making love to another man's fiancee.
That's all right, Walter. It's as much my fault as yours.
Bruce is making the nine o'clock train. I told him you'd be on it -- unless you want to write this story yourself.
Well, if it's my last story, I'd like it to be a good one. But -- I guess I can't, Walter.
Suit yourself, kid. This isn't for me to decide. Of course, you could make a later train and still be in Albany tomorrow morning.
Albany... tomorrow morning... That's... that's giving up everything, isn't it?
He's going to have you the rest of his life, Hildy. Can't you give me another hour?
Another hour... Walter, you always were a master of timing. But no. No, I can't. It's over.
A coin? Really, Walter? After all this? You want to leave my entire future to chance?

24283.content: The greatest yarn ever written by anybody. My hat's off to you, Hildy!
Thanks.
And what a way to quit. While you're still champion! That's the way to leave, Hildy!
Yeah. Only -- only I'm not leaving, Walter.
What do you mean? Bruce'll be waiting for you in Albany.
Bruce can wait. I'm staying right here, Walter. I'm going back to work.
Where'd you wire him?
I didn't wire him.
Sure.
Walter, I'm telling you the truth! I didn't wire him. I just told him I was coming back.
Both jobs are open, Hildy. The paper -- and being Mrs. Walter Burns.
Oh, Walter... you haven't changed a bit.

Sure, it was good -- it was wonderful! Only you expected it to be like other marriages. It can't be like other marriages -- we're different! We're a different world. Look at what we went through today. I wouldn't trade that for any honeymoon in the world. I bet you wouldn't, either.
You'd trade honeymoons for front page stories, wouldn't you?

That's what makes it romantic. Every other married couple goes away on a honeymoon and for two weeks the bride knows just where the groom is, and vice versa. But us -- you never know where I am and I'm not sure where you are. That's Romance!
You're impossible.
Hildy, if that's what you want, all right. We'll even go to -- how about Niagara Falls?
Walter, you are the most... the ...
Sure I do. And I'll tell you something else -- I'd like a baby.
A baby?!
Sure, I can't last forever. I want a son I can train to take my place on this paper.
You want a ? You never mentioned a son! You just said a baby!
Well, if she looked like you -- Say! My brains and your looks -- that mightn't be such a bad combination.
Walter!
What's the good of arguing about something that probably doesn't exist? Look, Hildy, I'm proposing to you. What do you say?
Oh, Walter... I... I don't know what to say.
I don't want to rush you. Take a couple of seconds.

2429.content: It's just... you've been acting kinda strange, you know?
I don't know. You seem... different. You make weird jokes. Your accents changed. You don't even walk the same.
Different how? I am functioning within normal parameters. My core programming remains intact.
I can't put my finger on it, but everything's a bit off. Even the dinner tonight. It was beautiful, but...
But? Please elaborate. My analysis indicates a high probability you are experiencing discomfort. Identifying the source of this discomfort is paramount to resolving it.

24315.content: Karen.  I haven't been pleasant this weekend.
We've all seemed a little tense lately...
Come to think of it, I haven't been very pleasant for weeks. For that, I'm truly sorry. More than any two people I know, I don't want you and Lloyd to be angry with me...
We're never deeply angry, we just get sore. The way you do. We know you too well...
So many people - know me. I wish I did. I wish someone would tell be about me...
Oh, darling, if only it were that simple. People  you things, but truly  yourself... that's a journey. And sometimes a rather prickly one.

And what is that? Besides something spelled out in light bulbs, I mean. Besides something called temperament, which consists mostly of swooping about on a broomstick creaming at the top of my voice... infants behave the way I do, you know. They carry on and misbehave - they'd get drunk if they knew how - when they can't have what they want. When they feel unwanted and insecure - or unloved.

24324.content: More than anything in this world, I love Bill. And I want Bill. I want him to want me. But me. Not Margo Channing. And if I can't tell they apart - how can he?
Why should he - and why should you?
Oh, you think I'm being foolish, don't you? Romantic. But it's not about romance. It's about... recognition. He sees  in me.
Margo. Bill is all of eight years younger than you.
Don't remind me. It's not the age, it's the... the . He's looking at the future, and I...
Not to you. Not to Bill.
Exactly. I'm the past. A beautiful, fading past, perhaps, but the past nonetheless.

24360.content: Rosehill Avenue. No roses. No hill. And it's certainly not an avenue.
You need trees for an avenue.
There was talk of planting some when we first came.
Was there? Well, that was ten years ago. I haven't seen a sapling yet. Just a long, straight road with houses on either side. A street, really.

24385.content: From what would I be running?
You're always after truth - on the stage. What about off?
Then face it. I have. Since that first night - here - in the dressing room.
That was a long time ago, wasn't it? A different life.
When you told me that whatever I became, it would be because of you-
I said a lot of things back then. Young and full of… conviction.
And you blossomed. You became everything I thought you could be, and more. A star. It was… gratifying.
You hear all kinds of things.
Find out? What are you implying, Stella? This feels… deliberate. You’ve been circling around something for the last five minutes. Just  it.

24411.content: After you change, if you're not busy elsewhere, we can have supper.
I'd love to! Or should I pretend I'm busy?
Let's have a minimum of pretending. I'll want to do a column about you-
I'm not enough for a paragraph.

- perhaps more than one. There's so much I want to know. I've heard your story in bits and pieces... your home in Wisconsin, your tragic marriage, your financial attachment to Margo - it started in San Francisco, didn't it?  I say - your idolatry of Margo started in San Francisco, didn't it?
San Francisco was… significant. It was where I first  Margo. And yes, Wisconsin was home. A very long time ago.
San Francisco. An oasis of civilization in the California desert. Tell me, do you share my high opinion of San Francisco?
It held a certain… allure. A vibrancy. Though, I found it a bit overwhelming, truthfully. Too much striving, too much… . Wisconsin was quieter. More genuine, perhaps.
And that memorable night when Margo first dazzled you from the stage - which theater was it in San Francisco? Was it - the Shubert?
It was the Geary. A small, intimate theater. Perfect for… for what happened that night. She was performing in a revival of .
A fine old theater, the Shubert. Full of tradition, untouched by the earthquake - so sorry - fire... by the way, what was your husband's name?
It was the Geary, actually. Not the Shubert. And my husband… his name was Arthur. Arthur Henley. A good man, in his way.

24421.content: - it's Addison, from start to finish, it drips with his brand of venom... taking advantage of a kid like that, twisting her words, making her say what he wanted her to say-
Where'd you get all that information?
She's been to see me, as a matter of fact she left just before you came in - you just missed her...
And she told you all this about Addison? About how he... manipulated this girl?
She wanted to explain about her interview, wanted to apologize to someone - and didn't dare face Margo...
So Eve came to  with this. That's... interesting. And you believe her? Completely? After everything?

24445.content: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-
- and you felt just like that talking to Addison.
In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-
Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?
No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.
Disgrace? That's a strong word. He was…provocative. He enjoyed dismantling people, certainly. But you were holding up remarkably well, all things considered.

You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

24446.content: Tell me. How did your lunch turn out - with the man from Hollywood?
Some vague promises of a test, that's all - if a particular part should come along, one of those things-
But the raves about your performance-
They don't mean anything. Not in Hollywood. They just... don't. It's all about who you know. And I don't know anyone. Not really.
Well. I think you're painting the picture a little darker than it is, really. If nothing else - and don't underestimate him - you have a powerful friend in Addison.
